elements.content: A three-dimensional non-interpenetrated octahedral channel type coordination polymer [{Cu(L1)2(Cl)}·Cl·(H2O)4]∝ (1) (L 1 = N,N′-bis-(3-pyridyl)terephthalamide) possessing an inclusion of chloride water cluster [Cl(H2O)4]− exhibits sequestering of partially hydrated fluoride [F(H2O)4]− via a single-crystal-to-single-crystal fashion as evident from single crystal X-ray diffraction and solid state 19F NMR.
elements.clean_text: A three-dimensional non-interpenetrated octahedral channel type coordination polymer [{Cu(L1)2(Cl)}⋅Cl⋅(H2O)4]∝ (1) (L 1 = N,N'-bis-(3-pyridyl)terephthalamide) possessing an inclusion of chloride water cluster [Cl(H2O)4]- exhibits sequestering of partially hydrated fluoride [F(H2O)4]- via a single-crystal-to-single-crystal fashion as evident from single crystal X-ray diffraction and solid state 19F NMR.

elements.content: Partially hydrated fluoride is arguably the important target for fluoride anion separation from aqueous media; the coordination polymer [{Cu(L1)2(Cl)}·Cl·(H2O)4]∝ (1) (L 1 = N,N′-bis-(3-pyridyl)terephthalamide) was exploited to exchange the lattice included chloride−water cluster [Cl(H2O)4]− with [F(H2O)4]− via a single-crystal-to-single-crystal fashion as evident from single crystal X-ray diffraction, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, and solid state 19F NMR.
elements.clean_text: Partially hydrated fluoride is arguably the important target for fluoride anion separation from aqueous media; the coordination polymer [{Cu(L1)2(Cl)}⋅Cl⋅(H2O)4]∝ (1) (L 1 = N,N'-bis-(3-pyridyl)terephthalamide) was exploited to exchange the lattice included chloride-water cluster [Cl(H2O)4]- with [F(H2O)4]- via a single-crystal-to-single-crystal fashion as evident from single crystal X-ray diffraction, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, and solid state 19F NMR.

elements.content: It is important to remove fluoride from drinking water because of its adverse effect on human health; an excess concentration of F– may lead to dental fluorosis, deformities in red blood cells (RBCs), neurological disorder, etc. It may also affect the normal functioning of the liver, kidney, and digestive and respiratory systems. Because of its high hydration energy (which is also hydrophilic like SO4 2– as defined by the Hofmeister series), it is quite difficult to selectively separate F– from aqueous medium. It is therefore suggested that instead of naked F–, partially hydrated F– should be the target for separation. Nevertheless, various methods such as adsorption, ion-exchange, reverse osmosis, nanofiltration, and electrodialysis are being employed to defluorinate drinking water. Owing to its usual aqueous insolubility, a coordination polymer is important as it offers heterogeneous separation of anions. In particular, anion exchange via single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) fashion in coordination polymer (CP) is quite attractive as this process offers easy handling of the anion adsorbent. However, there are only a few reports on CP-based SCSC anion exchange, and to the best of our knowledge, no such reports are available concerning F– exchange via SCSC fashion. It may be worth mentioning here that Chen, Qian, and co-workers have reported a luminescent microporous metal–organic framework for the recognition and sensing of F–. In this communication, we report the exchange of partially hydrated fluoride [F(H2O)4]− by using a three-dimensional (3-D) non-interpenetrated octahedral channel (3DNIOC) type CuII CP derived from a bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligand L1 (Scheme ) in a SCSC fashion. 3DNIOC topology is attractive because of its robust open-framework structure. The strategy to build 3DNIOC topology is to thread two-dimensional (2-D) sheets by pillaring through a bridging ligand. Zaworotko and Hosseini have demonstrated that the SiF6 2– anion can be used as a pillar ligand to construct such 3DNIOC topology. In a recent communication, we have demonstrated that Cl– can also act as a bridging ligand in constructing a 3DNIOC type CuII CP and realized that due to its uni-negative charge unlike SiF6 2–, one more Cl– has to be present in the crystal lattice uncoordinated to the metal center which can be a potential target for anion exchange with F–. With this background, we have reacted two bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands, namely, N,N′-bis-(3-pyridyl)terephthalamide (L1) and N,N′-bis-(3-pyridyl) isophthalamide (L2) (Scheme ) separately with CuX2 (X = Cl, Br) (for synthesis see ).
elements.clean_text: It is important to remove fluoride from drinking water because of its adverse effect on human health; an excess concentration of F- may lead to dental fluorosis, deformities in red blood cells (RBCs), neurological disorder, etc. It may also affect the normal functioning of the liver, kidney, and digestive and respiratory systems. Because of its high hydration energy (which is also hydrophilic like SO4 2- as defined by the Hofmeister series), it is quite difficult to selectively separate F- from aqueous medium. It is therefore suggested that instead of naked F-, partially hydrated F- should be the target for separation. Nevertheless, various methods such as adsorption, ion-exchange, reverse osmosis, nanofiltration, and electrodialysis are being employed to defluorinate drinking water. Owing to its usual aqueous insolubility, a coordination polymer is important as it offers heterogeneous separation of anions. In particular, anion exchange via single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) fashion in coordination polymer (CP) is quite attractive as this process offers easy handling of the anion adsorbent. However, there are only a few reports on CP-based SCSC anion exchange, and to the best of our knowledge, no such reports are available concerning F- exchange via SCSC fashion. It may be worth mentioning here that Chen, Qian, and co-workers have reported a luminescent microporous metal-organic framework for the recognition and sensing of F-. In this communication, we report the exchange of partially hydrated fluoride [F(H2O)4]- by using a three-dimensional (3-D) non-interpenetrated octahedral channel (3DNIOC) type CuII CP derived from a bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligand L1 (Scheme ) in a SCSC fashion. 3DNIOC topology is attractive because of its robust open-framework structure. The strategy to build 3DNIOC topology is to thread two-dimensional (2-D) sheets by pillaring through a bridging ligand. Zaworotko and Hosseini have demonstrated that the SiF6 2- anion can be used as a pillar ligand to construct such 3DNIOC topology. In a recent communication, we have demonstrated that Cl- can also act as a bridging ligand in constructing a 3DNIOC type CuII CP and realized that due to its uni-negative charge unlike SiF6 2-, one more Cl- has to be present in the crystal lattice uncoordinated to the metal center which can be a potential target for anion exchange with F-. With this background, we have reacted two bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands, namely, N,N'-bis-(3-pyridyl)terephthalamide (L1) and N,N'-bis-(3-pyridyl) isophthalamide (L2) (Scheme ) separately with CuX2 (X = Cl, Br) (for synthesis see ).

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic id="gr7" orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="cg-2012-00279z_0004.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

When L1 was reacted with CuX2 (X = Cl/Br) in DMSO/MeCN in a 1:2 (metal/ligand) molar ratio, two isomorphous coordination polymers, namely, [{Cu(L1)2(Cl)}·Cl·(H2O)4·Y]∝ (1) and [{Cu(L1)2(Br)}·Br·(H2O)4·Y]∝ (2) were isolated, whereas a similar reaction of L2 in MeOH/EtOH–water resulted also in two isomorphous crystals, namely, [{Cu(L2)2(Cl)}·Cl·(H2O)3·Y]∝ (3) and [{Cu(L2)2(Br)}·Br·(H2O)3·Y]∝ (4) [Y = disordered solvents] (structure of 4 could not be determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD); the formula was based on cell dimensions and elemental analysis; ). SXRD analysis revealed that 1–2 belonged to the centrosymmetric tetragonal P4/n space group (Table S1, see ). The asymmetric unit of 1 was comprised of one-fourth of CuII, one-fourth of Cl– (sitting on a 4-fold symmetry axis coordinated to CuII), one-half of the ligand L1 molecule located on a 2-fold axis (also coordinated to CuII), one-fourth of the counteranion Cl– disordered around a 4 fold axis with an electron density peak amounting to 4.52 e/Å3, and a molecule of water. The metal center CuII displayed a slightly distorted octahedral geometry [∠N–Cu–N = 89.977(9)–89.980(9)°, ∠N–Cu–Cl = 91.11(14)°]; the equatorial positions of the metal center are coordinated by the pyridyl N atoms of the ligand L1, and the apical positions are occupied by the Cl– (Figure ). The extended coordination of L1 with CuII led to the formation of a 2-D corrugated grid architecture. Such 2-D grids are further threaded by a chloride bridge that leads to the formation of a 3DNIOC topology. Inside the channel, a Cl–/water cluster [Cl(H2O)4]− is located around a 4-fold symmetry axis sustained by O–H···Cl and N–H···O interactions involving the counteranion Cl– and lattice included water, and amide N–H and O atoms of the lattice included water, respectively [N···O = 2.957(8)Å; ∠N–H···O = 160.0°; O···Cl = 2.8867–3.0943 Å] (Figure ). The crystal structure of 2 being isomorphous with 1 displayed identical supramolecular structure. It may be important to note that such host materials for [X(H2O) n ]− cluster (where X = Cl, Br, and I and n = integer) are very rare.
elements.clean_text: When L1 was reacted with CuX2 (X = Cl/Br) in DMSO/MeCN in a 1:2 (metal/ligand) molar ratio, two isomorphous coordination polymers, namely, [{Cu(L1)2(Cl)}⋅Cl⋅(H2O)4⋅Y]∝ (1) and [{Cu(L1)2(Br)}⋅Br⋅(H2O)4⋅Y]∝ (2) were isolated, whereas a similar reaction of L2 in MeOH/EtOH-water resulted also in two isomorphous crystals, namely, [{Cu(L2)2(Cl)}⋅Cl⋅(H2O)3⋅Y]∝ (3) and [{Cu(L2)2(Br)}⋅Br⋅(H2O)3⋅Y]∝ (4) [Y = disordered solvents] (structure of 4 could not be determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD); the formula was based on cell dimensions and elemental analysis; ). SXRD analysis revealed that 1-2 belonged to the centrosymmetric tetragonal P4/n space group (Table S1, see ). The asymmetric unit of 1 was comprised of one-fourth of CuII, one-fourth of Cl- (sitting on a 4-fold symmetry axis coordinated to CuII), one-half of the ligand L1 molecule located on a 2-fold axis (also coordinated to CuII), one-fourth of the counteranion Cl- disordered around a 4 fold axis with an electron density peak amounting to 4.52 e/Å3, and a molecule of water. The metal center CuII displayed a slightly distorted octahedral geometry [∠N-Cu-N = 89.977(9)-89.980(9)°, ∠N-Cu-Cl = 91.11(14)°]; the equatorial positions of the metal center are coordinated by the pyridyl N atoms of the ligand L1, and the apical positions are occupied by the Cl- (Figure ). The extended coordination of L1 with CuII led to the formation of a 2-D corrugated grid architecture. Such 2-D grids are further threaded by a chloride bridge that leads to the formation of a 3DNIOC topology. Inside the channel, a Cl-/water cluster [Cl(H2O)4]- is located around a 4-fold symmetry axis sustained by O-H⋅⋅⋅Cl and N-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions involving the counteranion Cl- and lattice included water, and amide N-H and O atoms of the lattice included water, respectively [N⋅⋅⋅O = 2.957(8)Å; ∠N-H⋅⋅⋅O = 160.0°; O⋅⋅⋅Cl = 2.8867-3.0943 Å] (Figure ). The crystal structure of 2 being isomorphous with 1 displayed identical supramolecular structure. It may be important to note that such host materials for [X(H2O) n ]- cluster (where X = Cl, Br, and I and n = integer) are very rare.

elements.content: Metal coordination geometry in CP 1.

Crystal structure illustration of 1: (a) of 3D non-interpenetrated network wherein 2-D corrugated sheets are threaded by a chloride bridge (side view); (b) along the crystallographic axis c showing the microporous channel; (c) encapsulation of [Cl(H2O)4]− within the microporous channel of 1.
elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structure illustration of 1: (a) of 3D non-interpenetrated network wherein 2-D corrugated sheets are threaded by a chloride bridge (side view); (b) along the crystallographic axis c showing the microporous channel; (c) encapsulation of [Cl(H2O)4]- within the microporous channel of 1.

elements.content: Pale green colored crystals of 3 were obtained when L2 reacted with CuCl2 in a H2O–EtOH–MeOH solvent mixture. Crystals of 3 were crystallized in tetragonal P4bm space group (Table S1, see ). The asymmetric unit of 3 was comprised of one-fourth of CuII, one-fourth of Cl (both sitting on a 4-fold axis), one-half of the ligand L2 molecule located on a 2 fold axis (both L2 and Cl were coordinated to CuII), one-fourth of counteranion Cl and three molecule of water (both disordered around a 4 fold axis). The metal center CuII in 3 displayed a slightly distorted octahedral geometry [∠N–Cu–N = 89.995(4)°, ∠N–Cu–Cl = 89.43(13)–90.57(13)°]; the equatorial positions of the metal center are coordinated by the pyridyl N atoms of L2 and the apical positions are occupied by Cl. The extended metal–ligand coordination of CuII and L2 resulted in 2-D “egg tray” like architecture which is the primary supramolecular structure of 3. Further extension of metal–ligand coordination via a Cl bridge resulted in a 3DNIOC type network. The channels of 3 were occupied by counteranion Cl–, water molecules, and some unaccounted electron densities (75 e/Å3 per unit cell) presumably coming from disordered solvents. The water molecules were involved in hydrogen bonding with themselves [O···O = 2.7091–2.8791 Å], with counteranion chloride [O···Cl = 2.9026(1) Å] and amide OC [O···O = 2.8943 Å]. The counteranion Cl– is also involved in hydrogen bonding interaction with amide N–H [N···Cl = 3.1666 Å; ∠N–H···Cl = 168°]. These noncovalent interactions resulted in a polymeric [{Cl(H2O)3}−]∝ cluster and the coordination network of 3 acts as a receptor for such a kind of cluster (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: Pale green colored crystals of 3 were obtained when L2 reacted with CuCl2 in a H2O-EtOH-MeOH solvent mixture. Crystals of 3 were crystallized in tetragonal P4bm space group (Table S1, see ). The asymmetric unit of 3 was comprised of one-fourth of CuII, one-fourth of Cl (both sitting on a 4-fold axis), one-half of the ligand L2 molecule located on a 2 fold axis (both L2 and Cl were coordinated to CuII), one-fourth of counteranion Cl and three molecule of water (both disordered around a 4 fold axis). The metal center CuII in 3 displayed a slightly distorted octahedral geometry [∠N-Cu-N = 89.995(4)°, ∠N-Cu-Cl = 89.43(13)-90.57(13)°]; the equatorial positions of the metal center are coordinated by the pyridyl N atoms of L2 and the apical positions are occupied by Cl. The extended metal-ligand coordination of CuII and L2 resulted in 2-D "egg tray" like architecture which is the primary supramolecular structure of 3. Further extension of metal-ligand coordination via a Cl bridge resulted in a 3DNIOC type network. The channels of 3 were occupied by counteranion Cl-, water molecules, and some unaccounted electron densities (75 e/Å3 per unit cell) presumably coming from disordered solvents. The water molecules were involved in hydrogen bonding with themselves [O⋅⋅⋅O = 2.7091-2.8791 Å], with counteranion chloride [O⋅⋅⋅Cl = 2.9026(1) Å] and amide OC [O⋅⋅⋅O = 2.8943 Å]. The counteranion Cl- is also involved in hydrogen bonding interaction with amide N-H [N⋅⋅⋅Cl = 3.1666 Å; ∠N-H⋅⋅⋅Cl = 168°]. These noncovalent interactions resulted in a polymeric [{Cl(H2O)3}-]∝ cluster and the coordination network of 3 acts as a receptor for such a kind of cluster (Figure ).

elements.content: Crystal structure illustration of 3: (a) 2D corrugated sheet; (b) 2D corrugated grids are pillared with chlorine to form a 3DNIOC topology; (c) 3DNIOC topology of 3 wherein the entrapped [{Cl(H2O)3}−]∝ shown in space filled model (water O – red and Cl – green).
elements.clean_text: 3  Crystal structure illustration of 3: (a) 2D corrugated sheet; (b) 2D corrugated grids are pillared with chlorine to form a 3DNIOC topology; (c) 3DNIOC topology of 3 wherein the entrapped [{Cl(H2O)3}-]∝ shown in space filled model (water O - red and Cl - green).

elements.content: Some unaccounted electron densities present at the final stages of the refinement of 1–3 (as state above) were SQUEEZED out, and thermogravimetric analyses were found be consistent with the crystal structures (Figures S1–S3, ).
elements.clean_text: Some unaccounted electron densities present at the final stages of the refinement of 1-3 (as state above) were SQUEEZED out, and thermogravimetric analyses were found be consistent with the crystal structures (Figures S1-S3, ).

elements.content: Single crystal structures of 1–3 revealed that this type of 3DNIOC network capable of encaging a halide/water cluster is suitable for fluoride exchange for the reasons stated above. To demonstrate the proof of the concept, we soaked a batch of single crystals of 1 (here after designated as 1F) in a saturated acteonitrile solution containing [(Bu)4NF] for approximately 12 min (Figure ); one such soaked crystal of 1F was then subjected to SXRD; soaking for more than 12 min resulted in crystals not suitable for SXRD data collection (vide infra) (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: Single crystal structures of 1-3 revealed that this type of 3DNIOC network capable of encaging a halide/water cluster is suitable for fluoride exchange for the reasons stated above. To demonstrate the proof of the concept, we soaked a batch of single crystals of 1 (here after designated as 1F) in a saturated acteonitrile solution containing [(Bu)4NF] for approximately 12 min (Figure ); one such soaked crystal of 1F was then subjected to SXRD; soaking for more than 12 min resulted in crystals not suitable for SXRD data collection (vide infra) (Figure ).

elements.content: SCSC fluoride exchange of [Cl(H2O)4]− and [F(H2O)4]− are shown in space-fill model with color code Cl – green, O – red, F – orange.
elements.clean_text: 4  SCSC fluoride exchange of [Cl(H2O)4]- and [F(H2O)4]- are shown in space-fill model with color code Cl - green, O - red, F - orange.

elements.content: The microscopic photographs of SCSC fluoride exchange experiment: after immersion of the crystals of 1 in 0.05 N (Bu)4NF solution in CH3CN; image after (a) 2 min; (b) 4 min; (c) 6 min; (d) 8 min; (e) 10 min; (f) 12 min; (g) 14 min; (h) 16 min.
elements.clean_text: 5  The microscopic photographs of SCSC fluoride exchange experiment: after immersion of the crystals of 1 in 0.05 N (Bu)4NF solution in CH3CN; image after (a) 2 min; (b) 4 min; (c) 6 min; (d) 8 min; (e) 10 min; (f) 12 min; (g) 14 min; (h) 16 min.

elements.content: The X-ray analysis revealed that 1 and 1F were isomorphous as indicated from their similar cell dimensions and identical space group (Table S1 ). During structure solution and refinement of 1F, it was observed that an electron density peak amounting to 1.91 e/Å3 was located around a 4-fold axis. Considering this peak as a rotationally disordered F– anion around a 4-fold axis having a site occupancy factor (SOF) of 0.25, the total electron density for this peak amounts to 1.91 × 4 = 7.64 e/Å3, meaning that it could be coming from a F– anion. The anisotropic refinement went well displaying reasonably acceptable principal mean-square displacement parameters (PMDP) (0.2223, 0.0538, 0.03) of this F atom. If the refinement was performed considering this electron density peak as Cl–, the corresponding PMDP shot up to a higher value of 0.3118, 0.1218, 0.0854, indicating that this electron density peak was really due to the F atom. Further support to this SCSC anion exchange could be strengthened from the fact that when Cl– was considered as F– in the original unsoaked crystal of 1, expectedly it failed to refine displaying nonpositive-definite (NPD) to the F atom. The fact that the data of 1F allowed better anisotropic refinement of the F atom compared to that of the Cl atom in 1 clearly established that a SCSC anion exchange had really taken place. To rule out the possibility of a solution-mediated recrystallization mechanism of this anion exchange, time-resolved optical microscopy experiments were performed. In this experiment, a batch single crystals of 1 was soaked in 0.05 M solution (Bu)4NF in acteonitrile. It can be clearly seen from the Figure that the crystal remained unchanged for 12 min and then started to crack. Since the SXRD data of 1F was collected after soaking the crystal for 12 min, it could be concluded that the anion exchange process indeed took place via SCSC fashion. As 1 and 1F are isomorphous, the corresponding simulated and bulk powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns expectedly turned out to be nearly superimposable making it difficult to conclusively establish the process as SCSC (); the slight mismatch of the PXRD pattern (prominent peak at 7–8°) of the bulk crystals of 1F with that of its simulated pattern could be due to the presence of other crystalline morphs (unknown) which we could not establish.
elements.clean_text: The X-ray analysis revealed that 1 and 1F were isomorphous as indicated from their similar cell dimensions and identical space group (Table S1 ). During structure solution and refinement of 1F, it was observed that an electron density peak amounting to 1.91 e/Å3 was located around a 4-fold axis. Considering this peak as a rotationally disordered F- anion around a 4-fold axis having a site occupancy factor (SOF) of 0.25, the total electron density for this peak amounts to 1.91 × 4 = 7.64 e/Å3, meaning that it could be coming from a F- anion. The anisotropic refinement went well displaying reasonably acceptable principal mean-square displacement parameters (PMDP) (0.2223, 0.0538, 0.03) of this F atom. If the refinement was performed considering this electron density peak as Cl-, the corresponding PMDP shot up to a higher value of 0.3118, 0.1218, 0.0854, indicating that this electron density peak was really due to the F atom. Further support to this SCSC anion exchange could be strengthened from the fact that when Cl- was considered as F- in the original unsoaked crystal of 1, expectedly it failed to refine displaying nonpositive-definite (NPD) to the F atom. The fact that the data of 1F allowed better anisotropic refinement of the F atom compared to that of the Cl atom in 1 clearly established that a SCSC anion exchange had really taken place. To rule out the possibility of a solution-mediated recrystallization mechanism of this anion exchange, time-resolved optical microscopy experiments were performed. In this experiment, a batch single crystals of 1 was soaked in 0.05 M solution (Bu)4NF in acteonitrile. It can be clearly seen from the Figure  that the crystal remained unchanged for 12 min and then started to crack. Since the SXRD data of 1F was collected after soaking the crystal for 12 min, it could be concluded that the anion exchange process indeed took place via SCSC fashion. As 1 and 1F are isomorphous, the corresponding simulated and bulk powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns expectedly turned out to be nearly superimposable making it difficult to conclusively establish the process as SCSC (); the slight mismatch of the PXRD pattern (prominent peak at 7-8°) of the bulk crystals of 1F with that of its simulated pattern could be due to the presence of other crystalline morphs (unknown) which we could not establish.

elements.content: Solid state 19F nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy was performed to characterize the presence of fluorine in 1F. The 19F MAS NMR spectrum of 1F, presented in Figure , exhibits two resonances, one centered at −108.9 ppm and a second centered at −123.6 ppm, indicating two different environments for 19F nuclei. By addition of supplementary Bu4NF directly in the NMR sample, we were able to assign the resonance centered at −108.9 ppm to residual Bu4NF used for fluoride exchange. The resonance at −123.6 ppm was assigned to the F– anion located in the microporous channel of 1F. It is worthwhile to mention here that we failed to wash out Bu4NF completely as can be seen in 19F NMR samples as well.
elements.clean_text: Solid state 19F nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy was performed to characterize the presence of fluorine in 1F. The 19F MAS NMR spectrum of 1F, presented in Figure , exhibits two resonances, one centered at -108.9 ppm and a second centered at -123.6 ppm, indicating two different environments for 19F nuclei. By addition of supplementary Bu4NF directly in the NMR sample, we were able to assign the resonance centered at -108.9 ppm to residual Bu4NF used for fluoride exchange. The resonance at -123.6 ppm was assigned to the F- anion located in the microporous channel of 1F. It is worthwhile to mention here that we failed to wash out Bu4NF completely as can be seen in 19F NMR samples as well.

elements.content: Solid state 19F MAS NMR spectrum (10 kHz) of [{Cu(L1)2(Cl)}·F·(H2O)4]∝ 1F. Recorded using a MAS-synchronized Hahn-echo. Spectral width of 200 ppm, number of scans 200, line broadening prior Fourier transformation of 50 Hz.
elements.clean_text: 6  Solid state 19F MAS NMR spectrum (10 kHz) of [{Cu(L1)2(Cl)}⋅F⋅(H2O)4]∝ 1F. Recorded using a MAS-synchronized Hahn-echo. Spectral width of 200 ppm, number of scans 200, line broadening prior Fourier transformation of 50 Hz.

elements.content: In summary, we have designed and synthesized a series of 3DNIOC type coordination polymers, namely, 1–3, by reacting separately two bis-pyridyl-bis-urea ligands (L1 and L2) with CuX2 (X = Cl/Br). SXRD studies revealed that all these crystals displayed 3DNIOC type topology highlighting the role of Cl– as a pillar ligand. Remarkably, halide–water clusters of the type [X(H2O)4] (wherein X = Cl and Br for 1 and 2, respectively) and [Cl(H2O)3]∞ were located within the crystal lattice. Since partially hydrated fluoride is argued to be a potential target for F– exchange, we have demonstrated the ability of 1 to exchange the encaged chloride water cluster [Cl(H2O)4]− with the partially hydrated fluoride [F(H2O)4]− via SCSC fashion as a proof of the concept. The fact that such F– exchange indeed took place via SCSC fashion was supported by SXRD and solid state 19F NMR. To the best of our knowledge such sequestering of fluoride–water cluster via SCSC anion exchange in coordination polymer is demonstrated for the first time.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have designed and synthesized a series of 3DNIOC type coordination polymers, namely, 1-3, by reacting separately two bis-pyridyl-bis-urea ligands (L1 and L2) with CuX2 (X = Cl/Br). SXRD studies revealed that all these crystals displayed 3DNIOC type topology highlighting the role of Cl- as a pillar ligand. Remarkably, halide-water clusters of the type [X(H2O)4] (wherein X = Cl and Br for 1 and 2, respectively) and [Cl(H2O)3]∞ were located within the crystal lattice. Since partially hydrated fluoride is argued to be a potential target for F- exchange, we have demonstrated the ability of 1 to exchange the encaged chloride water cluster [Cl(H2O)4]- with the partially hydrated fluoride [F(H2O)4]- via SCSC fashion as a proof of the concept. The fact that such F- exchange indeed took place via SCSC fashion was supported by SXRD and solid state 19F NMR. To the best of our knowledge such sequestering of fluoride-water cluster via SCSC anion exchange in coordination polymer is demonstrated for the first time.

elements.content: Synthesis and characterization of 1–4 and 1F, molecular plots and hydrogen bonding parameters of 1–3 and 1F, SQUEEZE results and TGA data of 1–3, X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) comparison plots of 1–3 and crystallographic data (CIFs) of 1F and 1–3. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Synthesis and characterization of 1-4 and 1F, molecular plots and hydrogen bonding parameters of 1-3 and 1F, SQUEEZE results and TGA data of 1-3, X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) comparison plots of 1-3 and crystallographic data (CIFs) of 1F and 1-3. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.content:
The authors declare no competing financial interest.

References

X-ray crystallography: X-ray single crystal data were collected 101 using MoKα (λ = 0.7107 Å) radiation on a SMART APEX 102 diffractometer equipped with a CCD area detector. Data 103 collection, data reduction, structure solution/refinement were 104 carried out using the software package of SMART APEX. All 105 structures were solved by direct method and refined in a 106 routine manner. In most of the cases, non-hydrogen atoms 107 were treated anisotropically. Whenever possible, the hydrogen 108 atoms were located on a difference Fourier map and refined. In 109 other cases, the hydrogen atoms were geometrically fixed.
elements.clean_text:
The authors declare no competing financial interest.

References

X-ray crystallography: X-ray single crystal data were collected 101 using MoKα (λ = 0.7107 Å) radiation on a SMART APEX 102 diffractometer equipped with a CCD area detector. Data 103 collection, data reduction, structure solution/refinement were 104 carried out using the software package of SMART APEX. All 105 structures were solved by direct method and refined in a 106 routine manner. In most of the cases, non-hydrogen atoms 107 were treated anisotropically. Whenever possible, the hydrogen 108 atoms were located on a difference Fourier map and refined. In 109 other cases, the hydrogen atoms were geometrically fixed.

elements.content: 19NMR. Solid state 19F-NMR spectra were recorded at 30 °C on a widebore Bruker Avance II spectrometer operating at a 19F resonance frequency of 470.5 MHz. Magic angle sample spinning (MAS) was νr = 10 kHz. A MAS-synchronized Hahn-echo sequence (90°−τ–180°) with a time in between pulses, τ, of 100 μs (τ and the spinning speed νr were synchronized: τ = ν1) was used with a 90° pulse of 2.25 μs and a recycling delay of 5 s. All 19F NMR spectra are referenced against CF3COOH (−76.55 ppm). 19F is an ideal nucleus for the solid state NMR as it has a nuclear spin of 1/2, a natural abundance of 100% and so a high sensitivity.
elements.clean_text: 19NMR. Solid state 19F-NMR spectra were recorded at 30 °C on a widebore Bruker Avance II spectrometer operating at a 19F resonance frequency of 470.5 MHz. Magic angle sample spinning (MAS) was νr = 10 kHz. A MAS-synchronized Hahn-echo sequence (90°-τ-180°) with a time in between pulses, τ, of 100 μs (τ and the spinning speed νr were synchronized: τ = ν1) was used with a 90° pulse of 2.25 μs and a recycling delay of 5 s. All 19F NMR spectra are referenced against CF3COOH (-76.55 ppm). 19F is an ideal nucleus for the solid state NMR as it has a nuclear spin of 1/2, a natural abundance of 100% and so a high sensitivity.

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic id="gr7" orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="cg-2012-00279z_0004.tif"></graphic>
</fig>
Metal coordination geometry in CP 1.

Crystal structure illustration of 1: (a) of 3D non-interpenetrated network wherein 2-D corrugated sheets are threaded by a chloride bridge (side view); (b) along the crystallographic axis c showing the microporous channel; (c) encapsulation of [Cl(H2O)4]− within the microporous channel of 1.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structure illustration of 1: (a) of 3D non-interpenetrated network wherein 2-D corrugated sheets are threaded by a chloride bridge (side view); (b) along the crystallographic axis c showing the microporous channel; (c) encapsulation of [Cl(H2O)4]- within the microporous channel of 1.

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure illustration of 3: (a) 2D corrugated sheet; (b) 2D corrugated grids are pillared with chlorine to form a 3DNIOC topology; (c) 3DNIOC topology of 3 wherein the entrapped [{Cl(H2O)3}−]∝ shown in space filled model (water O – red and Cl – green).
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Crystal structure illustration of 3: (a) 2D corrugated sheet; (b) 2D corrugated grids are pillared with chlorine to form a 3DNIOC topology; (c) 3DNIOC topology of 3 wherein the entrapped [{Cl(H2O)3}-]∝ shown in space filled model (water O - red and Cl - green).

cln_elements.content: SCSC fluoride exchange of [Cl(H2O)4]− and [F(H2O)4]− are shown in space-fill model with color code Cl – green, O – red, F – orange.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  SCSC fluoride exchange of [Cl(H2O)4]- and [F(H2O)4]- are shown in space-fill model with color code Cl - green, O - red, F - orange.

cln_elements.content: The microscopic photographs of SCSC fluoride exchange experiment: after immersion of the crystals of 1 in 0.05 N (Bu)4NF solution in CH3CN; image after (a) 2 min; (b) 4 min; (c) 6 min; (d) 8 min; (e) 10 min; (f) 12 min; (g) 14 min; (h) 16 min.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  The microscopic photographs of SCSC fluoride exchange experiment: after immersion of the crystals of 1 in 0.05 N (Bu)4NF solution in CH3CN; image after (a) 2 min; (b) 4 min; (c) 6 min; (d) 8 min; (e) 10 min; (f) 12 min; (g) 14 min; (h) 16 min.

cln_elements.content: Solid state 19F MAS NMR spectrum (10 kHz) of [{Cu(L1)2(Cl)}·F·(H2O)4]∝ 1F. Recorded using a MAS-synchronized Hahn-echo. Spectral width of 200 ppm, number of scans 200, line broadening prior Fourier transformation of 50 Hz.
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  Solid state 19F MAS NMR spectrum (10 kHz) of [{Cu(L1)2(Cl)}⋅F⋅(H2O)4]∝ 1F. Recorded using a MAS-synchronized Hahn-echo. Spectral width of 200 ppm, number of scans 200, line broadening prior Fourier transformation of 50 Hz.
